title: The Fabric of Reality
author: David Deutsch
summary: An extraordinary and challenging synthesis of ideas uniting Quantum Theory, and the theories of Computation, Knowledge and Evolution, Deutsch's extraordinary book explores the deep connections between these strands which reveal the fabric of realityin which human actions and ideas play essential roles.

title: Physics and Philosophy: The Revolution in Modern Science,
author: Werner Heisenberg
summary: A brilliant scientist whose ideas altered our perception of the universe, Heisenberg is considered the father of quantum physics; he is most famous for the Uncertainty Principle, which states that quantum particles do not occupy a fixed, measurable position.

title: Decoding Reality: The Universe as Quantum Information
author: Vlatko Vedral
summary: In this engaging and mind-stretching account, Vlatko Vedral considers some of the deepest questions about the Universe and considers the implications of interpreting it in terms of information.

image: Introduction to Classic and Quantum computing.jpg
title: Introduction to Classic and Quantum computing
author: Thomas G. Wong
summary: Introduction to Classical and Quantum Computing is for students who want to learn quantum computing beyond a conceptual level, but who lack advanced training in mathematics

title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics
author: David Griffiths
summary: Changes and additions to the new edition of this classic textbook include a new chapter on symmetries, new problems and examples, improved explanations, more numerical problems to be worked on a computer, new applications to solid state physics, and consolidated treatment of time-dependent potentials.

title: Quantum Computer Science
author: N. David Mermin
summary: This book is a concise introduction to quantum computation, developing the basic elements of this new branch of computational theory without assuming any background in physics.

title: Quantum Computing Since Democritus
author: Scott Aaronson
summary: This book takes readers on a tour through some of the deepest ideas of maths, computer science and physics.

title: Circuit QED: Superconducting Qubits Coupled to Microwave Photons
author: Steven M. Girvin
summary: This chapter introduces the basic concepts of quantum information processing with superconducting quantum circuits.

title: Quantum Computation and Quantum Information
author: Isaac Chuang and Michael Nielsen
summary: This comprehensive textbook describes such remarkable effects as fast quantum algorithms, quantum teleportation, quantum cryptography, and quantum error

title: The Quantum Spy
author: David Ignatius
summary: From the best-selling author of The Director and Body of Lies comes a thrilling tale of global espionage, state-of-the-art technology, and unthinkable betrayal.

title: Six Ideas That Shaped Physics
author: Thomas A. Moore
summary: Thomas Moore designed SIX IDEAS to teach students: --to apply basic physical principles to realistic situations --to solve realistic problems --to resolve contradictions between their preconceptions and the laws of physics --to organize the ideas of physics into an integrated hierarchy.

image: The Strange World of Quantum Mechanics.jpg
title: The Strange World of Quantum Mechanics
author: Daniel F. Styer
summary: This is an exceptionally accessible, accurate, and nontechnical introduction to quantum mechanics. After briefly summarizing the differences between classical and quantum behavior, this engaging account considers the Stern-Gerlach experiment and its implications, treats the concepts of probability, and then discusses the Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen paradox and Bell's theorem.

image: Quantum Physics, What Everyone Needs to Know.jpg
title: Quantum Physics, What Everyone Needs to Know
author: Michael G. Raymer
summary: The book tackles questions as broad as the definition of a quantum state and as specific and timely as why the British government plans to spend 270 million GBP on quantum technology research in the next five years.

image: Totally Random, Why Nobody Understands Quantum Mechanics.jpg
title: Totally Random, Why Nobody Understands Quantum Mechanics
author: Tanya Bub and Jeffrey Bub
summary: Totally Random is a comic for the serious reader who wants to really understand the central mystery of quantum mechanics entanglement, what it is, what it means, and what you can do with it.

image: The Amazing Story of Quantum Mechanics.jpg
title: The Amazing Story of Quantum Mechanics
author: James Kakalios
summary: A highly entertaining exploration of the complicated science of quantum mechanics made easy to understand by way of pop culture.

title: An Introduction to Quantum Computing
author: Phillip Kaye, Raymond LaFlamme and Michele Mosca
summary: A highly entertaining exploration of the complicated science of quantum mechanics made easy to understand by way of pop culture.

title: Modern Quantum Mechanics
author: JJ Sakurai
summary: Modern Quantum Mechanics is a classic graduate level textbook, covering the main concepts from quantum mechanics in a clear, organized and engaging manner.

title: The Second Creation
author: Rober P. Crease & Charles C. Mann
summary: The Second Creation is a dramatic--and human--chronicle of scientific investigators at the last frontier of knowledge.

title: Picturing Quantum Processes
author: Bob Coecke and Aleks Kissinger
summary: The unique features of the quantum world are explained in this book through the language of diagrams, setting out an innovative visual method for presenting complex theories.

image: Verdades y mentiras de la física cuántica.jpeg
title: Verdades y mentiras de la física cuántica
author: Carlos Sabin
summary: In this work, Carlos Sabín attempts to disprove the most common erroneous beliefs and myths surrounding quantum physics, placing special emphasis on demonstrating that it is not something mysterious and incomprehensible

title: Wholeness and the Implicate Order
author: David Bohm
summary: In this classic work he develops a theory of quantum physics which treats the totality of existence as an unbroken whole.

title: Cracking quantum physics
author: Brian clegg
summary: Enter the invisible world of sub-atomic physics and discover the very core of existence. Cracking Quantum Physics takes you through every area of particle physics to clearly explain how our world was, and is, created, and breaks down the most complex theories into easily understandable elements.

image: Introduction to Classic and Quantum computing.jpg
title: Introduction to Classical and Quantum Computing
author: Thomas Wong
summary: ntroduction to Classical and Quantum Computing is for students who want to learn quantum computing beyond a conceptual level, but who lack advanced training in mathematics.

title: The Theory of Quantum Information
author: John Watrous
summary: This largely self-contained book on the theory of quantum information focuses on precise mathematical formulations and proofs of fundamental facts that form the foundation of the subject.

title: Quantum Mechanics and Path Integrals
author: Feynman & Hibbs
summary: With its clear explanations, comprehensive coverage, and contributions from renowned physicists, Quantum Mechanics and Path Integrals is an indispensable resource for students, professionals, and anyone interested in understanding the path integral technique and its applications in modern physics.

image: Quantum Chemistry and Computing for the Curious- Illustrated with Python and Qiskit.jpg
title: Quantum Chemistry and Computing for the Curious: Illustrated with Python and Qiskit
author: Keeper Layne Sharkey and Alain Chancé
summary: Acquire knowledge of quantum chemistry concepts, the postulates of quantum mechanics, and the foundations of quantum computing, and execute illustrations made with Python code, Qiskit, and open-source quantum chemistry packages

image: The Science of Can and Cant.jpg
title: The Science of Can and Cant
author: Chiara Marletto
summary: A luminous guide to how the radical new science of counterfactuals can reveal that the scope of the universe is greater, and more beautiful, than we ever imagined.
